So, there's a hypothetical police force between "do-nothings" and "shoot you for looking sideways" type characters which would maximize your freedom...and such a police force *would* be relatively pro-active, and not passive.
...The real question is "In what particular way?"

replies.author: @cgg2621
replies.text:
@petitio_principii Nah. Libertarianism in the US is nowadays used to signify a right wing ideology that is against censorship and wants more civil liberties than traditional conservatism (decriminalization of drugs, etc) but also wants very few or no restraints put on the free market. Also, 'liberal' has no association with the left to someone who is politically aware. Being left wing requires a certain economic philosophy that modern liberals and neoliberal parties like the Democrats do not subscribe to. There is a slight social democrat influence on the party which is the only thing distinguishing it from classical liberalism.

At the moderate end libertarians are basically conservatives who are more relaxed about things like marijuana and gay marriage (as long as no one has to actually conduct these marriages who feels the slightest discomfort), but at the extreme end you get thought leaders who defend child labour. It's closely associated with Objectivism. The word 'Libertarian' formerly described left-wing anarchism, though, which is why Chomsky identifies as a Libertarian Socialist. Some try to reclaim the older meaning. Anarchism is the only ideology I know of that wants to abolish the police, but not abolish law enforcement, while Libertarians want to keep the police in place but make sure they only intervene in cases of force (the anarchists say they aren't intervening in the interests of the people are the moment anyway, so it would make no difference or improve things if they were replaced with community law enforcement). I make no claim about my own beliefs.

@bosstowndynamics5488 I don't think it was meant to bring up Flint as an example for racial disparity per se, but more using the "black test", that is rephrasing the sentence with the same structure but fitting another context and seeing if that still is "not racist" (or sexist or homophob or antisemitic etc etc etc). It's basially a form of the veil of ignorance but specifically aimed at discriminatory language. (Veil of ignorance is the philosophical approach to assume a law or concept might fall back on you to see if you still would be comfortable with it, say "would you want to see death penalties used in sentencing based only on DNA evidence if it were you that is awaiting sentencing and you have got a bad DNA result that suggests your guilt" or "Would you still argue for the mandatory invasive Ultrasound, Senator, if it were prescribed for a vasectomy and thus applied to YOUR body?"). The "Black test" does not turn it around at you, but by replacing the object of presumed discrimination to something you can easier relate with, it makes the inherent discriminatory intent clearer to the listener... 

And you probably will agree with me that this rephrasing makes the inherent problem with ben's apologetic wording blatantly obvious and thus unmasks his hypocrisy easily.

replies.author: @abhinav-v2i
replies.text:
@MK-ms4uz Agnosticism is a claim to unknowability. Atheism is a claim to disbelief for lack of evidence. 
To make it clearer, consider this: A police detective tells his parter that it is impossible to know who the killer is. This is agnosticism. Agnostics believe it is impossible to know and be certain about the supernatural. 
A jury member discussing the culpability of the accused says he does does believe the accused is guilty because there is a lack of evidence. This is akin to atheism where the atheist does not believe in the supernatural because of lack of evidence. 

Do you believe there is sufficient evidence for the Rockwell landings? If not, you are in the nonbeliever camp which is the default position. Your belief in them is either based on evidence or personal experience. These would make you a believer.

A gnostic atheist is a person who claims to know God doesn't exist, and literally everyone is agnostic because no one truly knows if God exists or not.

replies.author: @bluedotdinosaur
replies.text:
Shifting the burden of proof is a primary opening gambit in discussion with people like Shapiro. It's actually what someone called a "brain stopping tactic". Flipping the burden of proof onto the questioner feels fundamentally unfair, and tends to catch people flat-footed. Their awkward freeze and inability to quickly realize what is happening, is then framed as them being "wrong", "ignorant" or simply "stupid".

And a big part of this kind of rhetoric is making people who disagree with you seem fabulously stupid. Because that makes the other people listening WANT to agree with you. They don't want to end up looking stupid as well.

author: @SlaughterHouseEducation
text:
"Everyone in jail has had a trial and plea" FALSE! POINT OF ORDER THIS IS FALSE! In American you are often sent to jail after being arrested - so WHILE you still have the presumption of innocence, before you either take a plea deal or have a trial. And if you can't make bail... So that's a basic knowledge of the criminal justice system fail on his part. He is correct though that there are innocent people in jail, for this exact reaction I just described. 
Obviously, people are not sent to prison without a trial or plea - but jail and prison are different things. Again, basic criminal justice stuff that Ben doesn't understand and then spews onto his viewers.

replies.author: @jpe1
replies.text: SlaughterHouse Education you say ‚Äúobviously jail and prison are different things‚Äù but that isn‚Äôt obvious to me at all... I look in my dictionary and under prison is says ‚Äúa jail‚Äù and under jail it says ‚Äúa prison‚Äù and I‚Äôve always heard those terms used interchangeably. replies.author: @mofinebovine1597
replies.text: @jpe1 the 2 terms are used interchangeably when referring to prison, but "prison" is specifically a holding facility for people that have been convicted of a crime.  Being put in a holding cell after arrest but before conviction is going to gaol (or jail)."Prison" means implicitly that there has been a conviction while "jail" is more vague.

replies.author: @jpe1
replies.text:
Mofine Bovine interesting.
I know the facility in which I was incarcerated was officially called a ‚Äúcorrectional institution‚Äù and all of the statutes and sentencing paperwork et cetera for my case never used the words ‚Äújail‚Äù or ‚Äúprison‚Äù or ‚Äúimprisonment‚Äù but always said ‚Äústate correctional institution‚Äù and ‚Äúincarceration‚Äù. Perhaps that was to avoid ambiguity of the words ‚Äújail‚Äù and ‚Äúprison.‚Äù

Graphics don't matter GAMES do Go find a single example of that ever happening. 
Even if you manage to find one (Heres a freebie, in fact! David Reimer) they're complete anomalies, are (when fully understood *eventually*, as in the case of Reimer) decried as abusive, and not at all indicative of best-practices in a modern medical setting.
A kid questioning their gender in 2020 isn't going to be marched into the doctors office (well, they aren't going to be any way, but that's neither here nor there) and have a knife taken to them. Years of counselling to make sure it isn't just a Kid being a Kid (I'm a dinosaur!) (IMO it's too many years, especially when the same "or maybe you're just stupid" approach is taken with fully consenting adults) and even when they DO believe the kid, the most that occurs is puberty blockers. Which are (to the best of our current knowledge) mostly completely reversible, and have the only effect of stasis, not change. 
If the kid turns out to be trans in truth, then putting them through the wrong puberty when it's fully possible to postpone it and medically induce the correct puberty for their gender is tantamount to abuse, and any medical cost a kid incurs later in life when reversing the damage of the incorrect puberty should be paid by whatever adult decided that fucking them up by letting 'nature' take its course is a Good Idea.

replies.author: @Descanlin
replies.text:
@willybilly4402 Read what I said. I didn't say anyone *is* fucked up, I said that they "fucked up." As in, did an into badthing mistakemake. 
As for the cost, I'm Canadian. Not all of that stuff is covered by our healthcare system (gender affirmative surgery is often considered 'elective' and 'cosmetic') but the stuff that children go through tends to be covered, and what isn't covered doesn't cost the hundreds of thousands of dollars an American would face. 
As for the snide "first world problems" thing, human beings are human beings and will do human things, like be more complicated than a binary innate dichotomy, and just because the west has a medicalized conception of gender non-conformation with surgery and hormone treatment, does not mean that people we would call transgender don't exist across the world. Everyone is racist. Some people embrace some emblem of racism which others reject. And some racism is systemic, or accepted by society, and others are not. 

A person could say that that anti white racism is rampant and another could say no because it can‚Äôt exist in white countries. But that doesn‚Äôt make the rebuttal true. replies.author: @UserJWR
replies.text: @FauxtakuLounge There is a difference between conditioning, conscious racism and acting on your racist beliefs. I often catch myself thinking obviously racist things. I live in a country where Turkish and Arab people are the biggest minority and they experience similar prejudices as black people in the US. When I see an Arab-looking person I often get more cautious in certain situations (at night on the street or in the night club) because I have been conditioned to think of them as dangerous and malicious. However, in my second thought I recognize the unfair prejudice and realize that I don't know this person and just because they look a certain way does not mean that they are inherently dangerous. So you could say that I am conditioned to react in a racist way. Does that mean I am racist? I don't think so. I think it's very important to differentiate between racist conditioning (which is more a systemic problem than an individual one) and actual conscious racism. And I think only those who embrace the latter are actual racists (on an individual level).

author: @jonah_da_mann
text:
There's a precept in criminal law called Blackstone's Ratio, which is basically the idea that it is better to let 10 guilty people roam freely than it is to risk punishing 1 innocent person for a crime which they did not commit.

As you spoke about stop and frisk and the war on drugs, I was frequently reminded of this quote from John Adams (the U.S. President), which ties into the above idea:

‚ÄúIt is more important to the public that innocence should be protected than it is that guilt should be punished, for guilt and crimes are so frequent in the world that, by definition, not all of them CAN be punished. And oftentimes when they happen, they happen in such a way that it is of little consequence to the public whether they are punished or not. However, when an innocent person is brought before the bar to be condemned, especially to die, then that person will think to himself: ‚Äòit is immaterial to me whether I do good or do evil, for innocence itself is no security.‚Äô And if such a sentiment as that were to take hold in the minds of the citizens, that would be the end of all security whatsoever.‚Äù

My theory is that modern American conservatives are actually "sour grapes" liberals, who despise true liberals even as they envy them, and so try to co-opt liberalism for their own purposes. Another "talking point" I hear all the time is "If America is so racist, why do so many non-European immigrants want to come here, even breaking the law to get in here?" Well, they've always been coming here, even during the past days of blatant racism. That's how desperate conditions were in their home countries. author: @bluedotdinosaur
text: The rhetoric of people like Shapiro is designed to prey on the urge of privileged people to shy away from troubling things with reasonable sounding excuses. When he claims "system racism" is vague and undefined - despite being something very well defined, documented, and backed up by data - he is appealing to the experiences of people who have likely never experienced system racism. Or if they've seen it applied to others, have tried to excuse it to themselves with rationalizations. To such people it might feel "vague" because it is something they keep hearing about but "never see". Therefore, Ben framing something that is heavily documented as being non-existent doesn't come across as disingenuous, but as a sensible observation.

author: @COEXISTential
text:
The biggest problem with Ben's position on systemic racism is that he clearly doesn't understand what it is. Listen to what he says in that first clip:
5:48  "...shouting institutional racism doesn't combat racism, you have to find individual instances, you have to show me who the racists are..."

Um, no, Ben. The racism may not even be intentional. The problem is that institutions tend to have rules, and those rules are often rigid and ignore context, and certainly ignore history. Any system that looks at familial wealth but ignores the impact of red-lining, any system that looks at African-American incarceration rates, but not at the arrest rates that precede them, is systemically racist.

Discussion of structural racism is an acknowledgement of biases in society along racial lines, whether intentional or not, not about explicit discrimination or hatred.

replies.author: @EsbenM
replies.text:
More like cause and effect. If you believe in the concept of red-pilling, you are already experiencing the Dunning‚ÄìKruger effect. I don't think anyone who invokes that term has ever considered the original meaning of "the desert of the real," where Neo is told about the Matrix. It's a complete bastardization of Jean Baudrillard's idea, to the point where it basically reverses it. He says that what is real and what is not is so difficult to comprehend, even when people use all their efforts to understand, they can still fail or be duped. 
In other words, you can never be red-pilled. Understanding the world is an ongoing and difficult effort that we will likely fail at. The concept of a red pill in itself is probably a 3rd stage simulacrum according to Baudrillard.

author: @ACGreyhound04
text:
Ben Shapiro is sort of an enigma to me. On one hand, he‚Äôs a Harvard Law School graduate who should be well-equipped to do real legal research, and easily find caselaw or policy papers to support any argument he cares to make, just with a quick search on Westlaw. On the other, his schtick is to easily ‚Äúdefeat‚Äù naive college students in debates using rhetorical parlor tricks like gish gallops, straw-manning and logical fallacies that anyone capable of getting a decent LSAT score would realize are weak. 

He‚Äôs like an NBA player spending most of his time crushing high school kids in games of HORSE at the YMCA, and using every dirty trick and technical foul to do it, not to coach them, or even to show them how much they still have to learn, but just to pump his own ego and legitimize his own preconceived notions, which ironically, the process of legal education should have drummed out of him.

I wonder: has he burned that many bridges in the legal world that he couldn‚Äôt get a real job at a law firm, corporation or law school despite his Ivy League sheepskin? Could he really hold his own in a courtroom or boardroom? As a lawyer myself, I‚Äôm very skeptical.

author: @ragalyiakos
text: The thing about voter ID laws is that they aren't NECCESSARILY racist, but they ARE racist in an American context. For example, in my country, Hungary, when you go to vote, you need to show a photo ID both to confirm who you are, and to confirm you are voting in the district you're living in. But, unlike in America, the national ID card is provided free of charge and the offices where you can get them are open five days a week, and also every person is automatically registered to vote in whichever district they reside in, also free of charge. As such, the only way requiring ID to vote would stop anyone from voting is if you lost your ID card, or changed your place of residency without informing the government. Unless the US provides a FEDERAL photo ID for free to every citizen, voter ID will remain fundamentally unconstitutional and racist.

author: @RedHeadedAuthor
text:
I made it 6 minutes in before I had to pause it before I screamed at Ben through the screen that if it is institutional that means it's SYSTEMIC and thus you cannot point out an "individual." 

These people just want to keep going with the idea of individualism and that only "bad people" are the racists when it's something that has been repeatedly studied and pointed out that the fact that we've for so long gone on that train of thought (individualism) that we've allowed the spread of racism and white supremacy to reach points where it is so ingrained in our culture that many of us don't even realize that we are upholding it and it's why concepts such as "white fragility" exist to explain the reaction people have when it's pointed out to them that their actions are racist or white supremacist. We're raised to believe that only the bad people are racist, so therefore since we're not a "bad person" we cannot be racist and we go to great lengths to prove we're not (see: "I have friends who are people of color!" or "I am not in the (insert group here)!") 

By pushing the individual = bad / system = good narrative, he's ignoring the very fact that while yes, some people can tick off all the boxes, for these issues, it is impossible at this point to fully separate a person from racism or white supremacy due to the very fact that the foundations of our own government (especially US and UK) are built on the ideas of white supremacy and that some people are "better than others." A SYSTEMIC issue isn't one that we can just go, "Here's the bad guy!" and instead we have to look at the systems in place and try to unravel them (which is FAR harder and more time consuming). It also means that we have to self reflect on how WE fit into the picture, especially if we come from a place where we are granted certain privileges due to aspects about ourselves. Even if we never wanted those privileges, even if those very privileges are in fact detrimental to us (see: White fragility), we have to acknowledge them and work to either undo them, or to use them in such a way as to say, give the mic to another group, or to steer conversations in different directions (such as bring attention to the issues on the reservations or MMIW that only seem to gain traction once "white" people start speaking up).

It is literally impossible to point out a single arbiter or racism like he's wanting, and he knows this. It's why he pushes for it and it's why his little parrots repeat it when dealing with others.

author: @bierrollerful
text:
To me, this stop and frisk policy seems like a self-fulfilling prophecy. Or rather: it's like gravity, just with crime & discrimination.
You assume that more crime is being done in some neighborhoods and so you go look for crime there. As you will find _some_ crime, this idea reinforces itself. As the idea grows, leading to more disproportionate searches, people in these neighborhoods will feel discriminated against, will lose their trust in the police, which itself can help to reinforce the idea. Even if the statistics say otherwise, this idea can be considered to be true as it validates itself _through its own_ actions.

author: @blurbphasic
text: I always knew the biggest indicator of intergenerational upward mobility was the house as an asset. It wasn't till I found out that the US government subsidized home loans in the 30's for decades while explicitly excluding blacks did I understand what institutional racism was about. The institution gave white families a huge benefit(rise of the white middle class anyone?) While denying the benefit to blacks. You can't just say, "fair lending laws will fix it" since those government loans were way easier to get, and now those who grew up with that benefit are far more likely to be accepted for loans now. It created a split in social mobility that 90 years later is still massively detrimental.

replies.author: @Kobolds_in_a_trenchcoat
replies.text: It was also welfare that was systematically denied to black people. Black people in Las Vegas actually had to form a welfare rights organization just to get the state to do literally anything for anyone in the state. The state reluctantly allowed welfare but the welfare director was an old guard constantly concerned with any little bit of possible abuse and desperately wanted any excuse to kick as many people off as possible lest anyone recieve even a single cent more than they were entitled to (regardless of how expensive and inefficient the means testing itself made the program). Needless to say, he was also a well loved conservative under Reagan and was his welfare advisor while president. There's an excellent and very readable book on the welfare rights organization in Vegas called "Storming Caesar's Palace" that I'd heavily recommend to anyone interested.

I listened to a talk by an economic historian called "The Steep Climb - the economic progress of African American men since emancipation" by Marianne Wanamaker and she painted a grim picture. Even when controlling for households with both parents there, black men were more likely to end up in a lower economic status each generation.

text: This is a minor point, but Rafael Mangual says "burglary" in his list of the supposedly serious and violent crimes that make up prison populations, but by definition "burglary" is non-violent, or at least, it specifically means that no threat of violence against a property owner was used in the theft (e.g. burglary is sneaky into a house and stealing something then getting out while robbery is specifically threatening someone with force to make them give something up)
